article_title: Why Chris Matthews' Obama interview matters
article_text:
On Media Blog Archives Select Date… December, 2015 November, 2015 October, 2015 September, 2015 August, 2015 July, 2015 June, 2015 May, 2015 April, 2015 March, 2015 February, 2015 January, 2015

Why Matthews' Obama interview matters

For almost a decade now, Chris Matthews has served as a barometer for baby-boom progressives' attitude toward Barack Obama -- from the "thrill" that went up his leg when he heard the presidential candidate speak in 2008 to the utter disappointment following last October's debate in Denver.

That's why Matthews' interview with Obama, which takes place at 2 p.m. today and airs at 7 p.m. on MSNBC, is a crucial one for the president, and for MSNBC.

For Obama: The last time the MSNBC vet interviewed Obama, at West Chester University in 2008, it was a love-in, the "thrill" having traveled up the leg and into the head and the heart. "How many of you are for this gentleman!" Matthews asked the audience.

Things have changed, obviously. 'Hope' and 'Change' gave way to insularity and ineffectiveness, and Obama is now perilously close to falling below a 40-percent approval rating. The liberal base is anywhere from frustrated to outraged over a litany of failed efforts and unfulfilled promises. The rollout of the Affordable Care Act, his signature legislation, continues to plague his legacy. The thrill, as Riley B. King said, is gone.

That doesn't mean you should expect Matthews to morph into Bill O'Reilly. He's still a liberal. Discussing the forthcoming interview this week, Matthews compared the disastrous Obamacare rollout to "a brilliant writer, perhaps, with a great theme who turns in a paper with a lot of misspelling or bad handwriting." That echoes Matthews' sentiments about everything Obama has done wrong, from the Denver performance to his reluctance to get on the phone with Republican lawmakers: Of course he's brilliant! He just can't close... often because he doesn't seem to want to. He lacks the Clintonian instinct.

It's ok for President Obama to be depicted as weak by Fox News -- they'll paint him that way no matter what -- and it's even tolerable for him to endure bad press on CNN (hey, it's just horse-race minutae, and no one's watching anyway). It is an entirely different thing for the president to lose Chris Matthews and MSNBC. What Matthews takes away from that interview will reverberate throughout the network's programming and shape the network's tone toward the president for the months ahead. That will in turn influence the attitudes of the base, and could determine whether Obama's approval rating heads into the high 30s or back toward the mid-40s.

For MSNBC: No major news outlet has supported Obama as much as MSNBC, and no major news outlet has been so shafted by him. Though it can sometimes seem like an arm of the White House and the DNC, MSNBC has an extraordinarily hard time booking Obama.

"The fact that President Obama has done Fox News, CNN, ABC, CBS and NBC -- what is the only major TV outlet that he has not done? He has not done us," MSNBC president Phil Griffin compained in October. Griffin attributed that to the fact that the president couldn't count on MSNBC giving him an easy interview. His interviewer, from The Hollywood Reporter, had a different theory: "Do you think Obama hasn't done an MSNBC interview because he thinks that everyone who watches MSNBC is going to vote for him anyway."

Matthews and MSNBC have a chance to display some journalistic integrity here. To push the president where he needs to be pushed and, after the interview, criticize him where he deserves criticism. In that October interview, Griffin said MSNBC was "not here to be the voice of the administration." This interview and its post-game analysis offer a trial run for that thesis.

For that reason, it's a good thing for MSNBC that the White House gave the interview to Matthews, rather than, say, Ed Schultz or Lawrence O'Donnell. Though often mocked by the right for his fawning statements about then-Sen. Obama, Matthews has been uninhibited in expressing his disappointment. Other MSNBC hosts seem to feign enthusiasm and outrage; with Matthews, you know where he stands.
